content.body: annevk: Anything you specifically you would like to see?  (such as updating the heading levels to the new standard scheme, etc).  I'm just making sure to stay within reason, etc.

hello! if I believe I've found some overlap in a working draft of CSSOM (compared to DOM2 core) with a notice about how the IDL is re-defining things, how would I go about helping the editor fix this? email them directly? scour IRC channels or lists? http://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-view/#dom-mouseevent-clientx seems to overlap with http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-2-Events/events.html#Events-MouseEvent-clientX (which is already recommended), for more conte
Email www-style⊙wo about it.
TabAtkins_: okie dokie
That said, DOM Level 2 Events isn't used, iirc.
TabAtkins_: it isn't used in what sense? like in the ES4 sense where it was dropped?
It's superseded by better specs.
TabAtkins_: ah, which specs?
is inb4 DOM Level 3 events
itym dom4
(fine, dom3 for the events themselves; but for the event model, dom4)
they have the same conflicts
All right then.
client{X,Y} and screen{X,Y} are supposed to be on MouseEvent interface
I wonder if we have an active editor for CSSOM-View...
I dont' think so.
yeah, was gonna email Anne, but she's may not be as active now?
Anne's a guy.
my bad
And has left the CSSWG, so he's not editting that spec any longer.
yeah
So, yeah, that's an editorless spec.
I didn't know that Anne left the CSSWG
Yeah, he dropped out a few months ago.
TabAtkins_: I don't supposed there'd be a point in mentioning this in my email to www-style and asking for volunteers?
suppose*
danbeam: Go ahead and mention it.  Make sure to put [cssom-view] in the subject line.
TabAtkins_: ok
Just so that future editors of that spec will be able to find it.
ya
wonders what Glenn Adams has been doing lately, since he hasn't seen much activity in the CSSOM spec recently...

TabAtkins_: so if CSSOM spec declares it added these to the MouseEvent interface, but they were in DOM Level 2 Events (which seems to be circa 2000, 11 years previous), should that part simply be removed from the CSSOM spec, essentially (given than an editor is found)?
s/spec/working draft/ for CSSOM (if that matters?)
Yeah, unless there's a good reason that CSSOM View should update the definitions, the DOM specs shoudl be definitive.
Given that D3E is more recent than View, too.
TabAtkins_: it seems to be the exact same thing
Then yes.
TabAtkins_: so nothing to update
wonders why there's only one person from Google that is active on www-style
kennyluck: I'm not particularly active, but I'm about to prove you wrong just the tiniest bit, :P
kennyluck: who were you referring to, Tab?
The editor that's listed currently.
kennyluck: editor of ... what?
danbeam, of CSSOM and CSSOM-view.
kennyluck: ah
oh, sorry I misunderstood you.
Ye
Yeah, I was referring to Tab of course.
so you're talking about shans@?
@google.com*
thought that you were asking who Glenn Adams is.
kennyluck: I know exactly who Glenn Adams is -- the smartest person I've [n]ever met with an @cox.com email!
:P
TabAtkins_: the editor's draft of CSSOM View seems to have new editors, should I be CC'ing/directing my question to shans⊙gc / glenn.adams⊙cc as well?
*shrug*. He only reminds me of a long thread about CORS and @font that I didn't look into.
kennyluck: haha, Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * everywhere! what's the worst that could happen?!
cbright6062: whatever you think is appropriate is fine
cbright6062: anything goes as long as it's still readable in recently released browsers
annevk: Okay.  And I will makeshore it is.
cbright6062: at least as far as I'm concerned, others in this channel might have different views
annevk: I mainly asked you since you have the main focus on the blog, from what I've seen :)
I think in the end the person doing the work should decide
lol
well, I'm doing the work, but I don't want to upset anyone on here :P
don't worry about it
ask forgiveness, not permission
danbeam: DOM Level whatever does not define hit testing and does not define the coordinates are given in CSS pixels
danbeam: having said that, TabAtkins_ is right, I'm no longer an editor or participant in the CSS WG
Poe's Law in action: http://stuffandnonsense.co.uk/blog/about/there_i_said_it
hsivonen: I don't think there's any suggestion that's a parody?
At least, if that's the intention — and I agree the content could be mistaken for parody — he fails to carry it through into the comments
Sadly I think there is just a school of thought that browsers are canvases for the artistic vision of web designers rather than tools that are designed to enable their users to access information
jgraham: Also, to pedant, transforms are Core Animation.
gsnedders: Fair point
But regardless, an API that exists only on OS X and their Windows-Safari port thing, seemingly.
Yes, my underlying point stands
(I wonder if Apple will ever release their Obj-C runtime for Windows?)
(I can't see it happening, but it raises interesting questions about Xcode being ported for the sake of iOS)
is puzzled by the last few lines of conversation
othermaciej: The context is that -webkit- CSS properties, in particular transforms, often have different implementations of the gfx part
different from what?
In different consumers of webkit
e.g. in Chrome vs Safari
oh, yeah, different ports have different graphics back ends, not just for transforms for that matter
(sorry that was very badly worded)
in fact I think transforms don't even use CA if they are 2D and not animated
othermaciej: The context is in Andy's blog post comments
(3D transforms and transforms with animation/transition applied do force a CA layer, I think other transforms are just done w/ CoreGraphics)

On the post hsivon linked to ther was lots of wailing about how Opera implementing some properties with the -webkit- prefix was evil because they might not have the same quality as "the" webkit implementation
Although there was never actually a conccrete example of this being a problem
And may differ subtly from it.
(which there is some basis for, given gradient syntax fun)
Or indeed any insight into why this isn't a problem for things without prefixes
I think people are starting with the conclusion that vendor A supporting vendor B's prefix is bad, and from there looking for arguments that may justify it
I'm not a huge fan of the situation but I can't blame anyone for doing whatever it takes to make their browser compatible with content
would quite like Apple to drop prefixed versions of properties, as everyone has done (albeit slowly)
Yeah, that would match my impression and explain why so many of the arguments seem so weak
I also don't like the situation fwiw, but I think the problem is with the prefix system
gsnedders: while that might be a good idea in general, for the most problematic properties, I am not sure that strategy is sane
Yeah, and something really should've happened when MS were going to implement… -webkit-text-size-adjust, was it, several years back.

because the specs are not advanced enough for the CSS WG to grant their blessing on shipping the unprefixed version at all, and the prefixed version is so widely used that not having it is major compatibility fail
I don't think it's reasonable, for the same reason I don't think it's reasonable for everyone else not to just implement those properties
othermaciej: For border-radius it's a change that can happen.
othermaciej: For gradients, yeah, it's less clear.
I think the CSS WG should confess that it failed and publish a CSS aliases spec
othermaciej: I believe you're now the only ones to support prefixed border-radius, FWIW
That makes support for the prefixed properties part of the standard
gsnedders: for border-radius it sounds like it would break a bunch of sites (assuming Opera's reason for implementing -webkit-border-radius is sound)
jgraham: In a wildcard sense, as glazou was proposing, or just specific ones?
gsnedders: I have no idea what glazou was proposing
othermaciej: That's a cosmetic issue, unlike the others. And it breaks them no more than Gecko dropping -moz- in 13.
not sure why Safari should take a compat hit in a case where Opera won't
But I would suggest specific ones
jgraham: -*-foo is mapped to foo
gsnedders: That makes no sense to me? What am I missing?
I mean, it seems to have all the properties of not having a prefix system whilst still having a porefix system
*prefix
othermaciej: I'd like to minimize the list of required synonyms, so we both would take the hit. I'm not gonna propsoe that for things like gradients where things actively become unusable.
I think prefix may be a failed experiment, at least as used today, but I am not sure how else to make it safe for browsers to experiment with extensions
othermaciej: The only sane thing I have heard is for extensions to be behind runtime flags
othermaciej: But given Moz has managed to drop prefix for border-radius it suggests it can be done.
Or not in stable versions
(Ourselves and MS never supported it with prefix)
Of course that isn't going to work well if "experiment" really means "add new features before anyone else and encourage authors to use them"
FWIW, border-radius would never have been aliased without the far more serious non-cosmetic issues.
I don't think it would fly to gate availability of features to content authors on the CSS WG's time to get to CR
I think the CSS WG is part of the problem
Ideally I'd like to only bake -webkit-linear-gradient (or whatever the name is) into the platform.
Because it's the only one sites *rely* on.
So a solution that forces change on them seems like a positive thing
(Possibly old flexbox, but hopefully what Google uses that on moves away from it)
I wonder also how early implementation should work for APIs, where the prefix approach is even worse
Because, as you say, people would push like crazy for a spec model that allowed fast iteration if their ability to ship was gated on fast itereation
annevk was suggesting second impl impls without prefix
(HTML attributes seem only about as bad as CSS properties when prefixed and no one holds those to a hard CR line)
othermaciej: Given the CSS WG agreed to drop things earlier than CR hopefully stuff is better in future.
gsnedders: by "drop things" you mean drop prefixes earlier than CR?
othermaciej: yeah
I thought the CSS WG explicitly refused to do that even in clear-cut cases
maybe I am not up to speed
I remember this in some f2f this be resolved.
I gotta ask hober since he goes to those things
I should probably just leave the WG given I never do anything anyway

anyway, CSS WG is touchy about their prefixes but I wonder if we can come up with sane cross-browser best practices for prefixing of APIs and markup attributes (I presume everyone would agree that prefixed elements are a bad idea)
Like, I every few months read the mailing list. Only otherwise do when people tell me to.
(In an unrelated point, Safari uses NSURL for all HTTPS stuff, so doesn't use NSS, right?)
I don't know what NSS is
we use CFNetwork for networking, via NSURL APIs on some OS versions
under the covers somewhere in there, I think OpenSSL is used for SSL stuff
SSL impl, used by Moz/Chrome
othermaciej: Shows how much time I've spent dealing with OS X that I don't even know that NSURL isn't current any more :)
NSURL is current, CFNetwork is just the thing underneath it
"some OS versions"?
(seeming NSURL predates Safari)
I think NSURLConnection was introduced along with Safari, actually. Looking at the docs: "Available in Mac OS X v10.2 with Safari 1.0 installed. Available in Mac OS X v10.2.7 and later."
on some platforms we just go to CFNetwork directly
Ah. NSURL itself goes back to 10.0
(don't believe it goes back to NS, though)
and yes, NSURLConnection was in fact introduced with Safari, it was first implemented by the Safari team
yeah, NSURLHandle existed before that, and is deprecated since 10.4
there was an older NSURLHandle which did not cut it for browser use
guesses he's in for fun working out what has changed in the past three OS X releases when he gets a MBA once they start shipping with Ivy Bridge CPUs
(Waiting mainly for the sake of GPU performance, which would probably be good enough to ditch my pretty old MBP)
Hello, does anybody know if there is a limit to HTML offline storage? I'm trying to find out if videos can be stored in it? Does anybody know that?
jgraham: It's quite possible that it isn't a parody, which is troubling.
See, I've seen plenty of people call it brilliant parody, but I fail to see any evidence of this.
othermaciej: I think the best practice for prefixing is not to
I'm rather surprised that Opera isn't aliasing Animations.
Once the aliasing code is there, why bother limiting what's aliased?
hsivonen: The limitation is probably to avoid too much of a backlash.
has no idea
What I think is sad about Opera's announcement is that some things that will have -webkit-aliases weren't announced to have unprefixed aliases, too
well, the other sad thing was blaming Web authors
blaming them isn't that productive and even if true, doesn't help
blaming the CSS WG might actually end up having helpful effects
and would be more correct direction of blame anyway

Except the discussions a couple of months back basically seemed resigned to the fact that non-WebKit browsers will have to support them, so all you can really do is blame prior WG decisions which have since been changed.
I'm not on the CSS WG, so I don't understand why layout devs act like CSS WG has the power to decide about unprefixing
The fact that plenty of sites we are just told, "we only support WebKit", is an issue purely down to developers, though.
seems like Opera aliasing but not also unprefixing is part of acting like it's in the WG's power to decide
gsnedders: ok
hsivonen: It's not official WG policy, pretty much, it's just de-facto agreements amongst browser vendors who happen to be in the WG, pretty much.
(wrt when to unprefix)
why do people who can land code keep honoring those de facto agreements?
Presumably fear of being called out on not supporting standards properly
hsivonen: The biggest issue is people doing background-image: -webkit-gradient(bleh); and refusing to put background-color: black; or whatever, which is down to more than just prefix policy.
gsnedders: interesting
Or a belief that the prefixing is a good idea, in spite of the evidence that it is harmful in these cases
hsivonen: Leading to white-on-white text, which is the real harm of this situation.
hsivonen: Everything else is merely cosmetic, and wouldn't have lead us to this.
Well white-on-white is an obvious "you can't use this site" bug
Other things are "your browser sucks more than $webkitBrowser even though it doesn't actually" issues
Which are also harmful
But not as harmful as to motivate anyone to risk the PR backlash we're currently getting.
I'm not sure I agree
Would have been nice to get Mozilla to make the change at the same time though
Or announce that they will
Well, I don't think anyone has seriously considered doing it based upon cosmetic reasons
jgraham: We rather had our hand forced, though, seeming someone posted what was W3C member-confidenial.
gsnedders: I thought there have been cosmetic reasons under discussion
gsnedders: I have certainly advocated aliasing to get cosmetic benefits
IIRC IE Mobile's planned support for -webkit-text-size-adjust was for usability issues
In the long term, cosmetic issues are just as important as "this site is broken" issues
Maybe moreso, because they are harder to evangelise
they have mindshare consequences
I think the hope was to come up with some cross-browser agreement about prefixes for them.
And UX consequences.
And for the current set of prefixes to go away.
what is an "XML Literal" and what purpose does it serve?
finds http://www.jenitennison.com/blog/node/103

MikeSmith: Its purpose is to confuse people by effectively being just a string that happens to contain markup, but technically being a string which is the UTF-8 decoding of an exclusive Canonical XML document fragment
ah
so it's the canonical part
Easiest to just think of it as a markup string
OK
but with some magic in the RDF parsers so that you can represent that string as actual markup
I see
I find that all sentences with "XML" in become transparent in meaning if you s/XML/pain/g
heh
so there context of this is, somebody is asking me if there's a "formal notion and/or algorithm that says whether two HTML5 snippets are identical or not"
but snippets I guess they mean nodes

(i.e. the magic lets you write

2

which turns into a string with value "2", I think)
Philip`: yeah, that looks like the example that Jeni uses in her blog entry
(per http://www.w3.org/TR/rdfa-syntax/#s_xml_literals except the spec forgets the xmlns, I think)
OK
I assume the point is to prevent you having to write escaped markup inside markup, since that's ugly
I see
so then I guess once you'd done this XMLLiteral thing, there are some cases where you want to be able to compare two XMLLiteral things to determine if they are identical with each other
not clear to me what those use cases are

Yeah, they're just strings, so you can do arbitrary stringy things to them, but they happen to have the C14N guarantee that string equality is implied by XPath data model equality (which is quite like DOM equality)
OK

which (I think) in theory means you could extract RDFa from some XHTML document 'A', and then you could fiddle with 'A' to produce 'B' (change all the namespaces, change irrelevant whitespace, etc, e.g. by passing through an XML parser then serialiser) and extract RDFa from 'B', and you'd get exactly the same output
th
about webvtt line wrapping, where should the line break go if there are two positions that would produce the same delta?
zcorpan: up to the implementation, i think, the balancing definition isn't precise (and should be loosened a bit more, to explicitly allow approximations)
zewt: that's annoying when writing tests :-)
tests how? it depends on the implementation's and platform's font rendering anyway
reftests
fwiw i want it to allow approximations so later the balanced wrapping can be made into a generic css white-space mode (where requiring it to be optimal isn't practical)
yeah i'm fine with allowing that, actually
it's still annoying
you can test extreme cases, which should always give results within certain limits
eg. if "a b c d e f g" wraps to "a b c d e f" and "g" in normal wrapping, it should always wrap closer to "a b c d", "e f g" in balanced
that is, in that case the balanced output should always be narrower than the regular output, even if it's an approximation
though since the balancing behavior is currently a special case rule instead of a CSS rule, I guess you can't turn it off in order to easily compare
hmm, also the spec doesn't say where to wrap words that are too long to fit
i guess you could check progressively longer cues ("foo", "foo foo", "foo foo foo", ...), and check that the width increases, and then decreases

that is, the width of the box will increase as long as it fits on one line, then it'll abruptly drop to about half the width as it inserts a break around the middle, and then start increasing again; that doesn't happen with regular wrapping
not a thorough test by any measure, but should at least tell whether it's happening at all
anyhow off to work, later
see ya
XML Core WG no like BOM
ok please tell me the editor's draft which seems to give an error right now doesn't do this silly renaming http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-text/#overflow-wrap0
zcorpan: no, fantasai hasn't got the memo that silly renaming is a bad idea

about MIME RFCs

"multipart/form-data filename encoding: unicode and special characters"

yup

nice!

MikeSmith: happy to turn it back on as soon as we can do it in a way that doesn't lead to people's feedback being lost :-)
